title: Decentralized tutoring marketplace
description: Finding an expert or monetizing your expertise requires centralized vetting services that limit your choices and control your access.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal seems like a great idea to use metadata based on actual monetary transactions to build reputations, focused initially in the academic tutoring space. Its not clear from the proposal, are you expecting transactions to happen on chain in ADA? It should be noted the proposers have submitted a basically the same idea into 5 other challenges, with different costs each time, though it fits reasonably well here.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers have outlined a relatively simple plan to get a minimal viable product up and running and have both the technical and domain expertise to get this going. It would be nice to see a little more about their plans to scale the project past the initial trial phase. Are they always going to need initial high cost vetting of tutors, or is there a way to decentralise this? Do they have ideas on how to make the ratings system objective rather than subjective? Ie based on outcomes of students? If rolled out at scale how do you stop tutors cheating and self dealing with themselves in round trip transactions then reviewing themselves? As the same proposal has been submitted 6 times with different budgets, I am not sure what they actually need to finance this.
f6_assessments.q2: This is a relatively simple proposal to deveop an MVP and as such clear milestones for progress have been presented. It would be nice to have some goals on the 6 and 12 moth timeline against which success is measured. How many tutors/students is successful (10,100,1000?). How much value through the market place?

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, it envisions an open educational plattform while cutting out the middleman which is very much what Decentralization stands for. It provides a great usecae for peer to peer smart contracts via the Cardano network and the field of technology-based education is experiencing a growing interest across the globe. I have seen new job listings for "digital education broker" so mainstream has picked up on the gap of educational options in the digital space and highly skilled academics/ teachers/ tutors/ individuals might want to escape the institutional grip. Providing a platform that would not limit participation to a region would provide access to educational choices. Great usecase. According to the guiding questions of this challenge: the needs addressed would be (but not limited to) to include plutus pioneers and share those skillsets through the platform, hence it addionally serves value onboarding criteria for Devs. It is a rather big project and it would be very nice to see it grow on the network.
f6_assessments.q1: A developer and a professor surely make a good team to start a digital educational platform. Prior experience points to a high likelyhood that the project will be successfully implemented. The team is transparent and already set up a discord chanel which is great to reach out to the community and keep the project running and set up a team of interested tutors. By including the specific group of "plutus pioneers" there is already a good measure of success criteria on how the first steps of tutoring via this exchange platform could look like, contentwise. Hiring plutus pioneers will also enhance trust in the plutus pioneer program and might attract more interested Devs to the Cardano Community. Since the project is spread out across some challenges it should be addressed if the proposers will implement the project if any of the other parts will not get funded.
f6_assessments.q2: Roadmap and milestones are feasable given the prior experience of the proposing team and that they have prior successful projects with the community. Risks of fraud have been addressed and will be avoided through feedback/ ratings and Zoom features. Success criteria would be more auditable if the proposers would include some simple numbers instead of broader terms like "a crop of tutors". The proposers should add adequate documentation of the project for the community to strenghten auditability and tranparency.

f6_assessments.q0:
- The online tutoring market is bigger than USD 4B, and it's expected to grow more than 16% until 2027. Therefore, I imagine this is a nice niche to be thinking of. However I've seen that the 'on demand' method is growing much more than the 'online tutoring' one. Therefore, it may be interesting for you to add this functionality.
- The proposal would enrich if there is some information or graphs about the online tutoring market and its expectations
f6_assessments.q1:
- It would be great to have an idea how many devs it would need and, then, you would be able to define how long we would have to wait to expect some functionalities – since without a complete team we can't judge if it's totally doable or not (I don't even know if the total budget requested to pay devs are too little or too much).
- As explained, the funds will be delivered after the review. However, it'll be a minimum score to distribute the money? The platform will possess a "complaint session"? I'm imagining that one of the parts could miss use the platform.
f6_assessments.q2:
- I am missing some metrics – what is a good number to start with? How many tutors and students, how are we expecting to grow and how long might we wait for this?
- Could you stratify a bit more the timetable in order to let us verify the bits of development?
- How many tutors it needs to start running?

f6_assessments.q0:
It has taken some time to go through the proposer's many proposals about tutorchain.io, but believe this is the one that is most fitting as they are proposing a DApp and need startup money to fund their plan.
I do think their project has good value to Cardano. I am concerned they may be using Catalyst more for marketing, but think their multiple submissions may be more about confusion of the Catalyst process (I am still a bit confused, but hopefully still providing value).
f6_assessments.q1: I believe this team has the qualifications to see this project to a point where it produces a proof-of-concept and pilot app using the funds provided. As a developer: they are probably needing to hire some Plutus and other technical consultants to "augment" their efforts, and so can calculate that would increase their success. The plan seems solid. The team seems experienced and compliment each other. Hopefully the team members being cousins equate a team staying together.
f6_assessments.q2: Information is well presented and seems mostly complete. I am concerned they provided it in multiple proposals, and that these proposals I would think should request funding for different aspects of the same proposal: and if so, that would be more acceptable. The multiple submissions on this team's part seems to be done due to confusion, but could be considered close to just marketing their tutorchain.io website, logo, and other presence. However, that doesn't change if the information provided is sufficient that provides metrics needed: and I do believe it does. I give higher stars to this proposal more than their others for I do believe it can bring value to Cardano, is a needed aspect for educational systems that are decentralizing, and that this one proposal out of their others is the most fitting to the DApp campaign.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal directly links to the goal of the challenge of increasing the utility of the Cardano ecosystem by providing a leading marketplace for tutors. It applied to multiple themes in Fund 6 such as the DLT entrepreneurship toolbox. Additionally, this seems like a really good start for a DAAP as it is not as complex as other marketplaces such as connecting hotels and travelers. This can also support the Cardano ecosystem with a tutoring platform for people wanting 1-1 sessions to learn about Plutus or Catalyst in the future.
f6_assessments.q1:
Overall the plan and budget are very comprehensible, let's get into the details. 

First, the experience and details on the team are well provided and they seem like suitable candidates to build this type of platform, however, I do believe that it could help Gabe (technical founder) to follow the Plutus pioneer program to be able to delegate and check work done by Plutus engineers if contracted later on.

Second, the plan seems reasonable and executable with the given timeline, with the goal of launching the platform in 12-months, and provides quarterly milestones. However, there are no mentions of already building a database of tutors and students prior to launch. I believe that it could be a key activity as usually the hardest problem to solve when launching a marketplace is the chicken and egg issue; how many suppliers (i.e. tutors) do we need to have buyers (i.e. students) for the platform to thrive.

Lastly, in regards to budget, there are very limited details in regards to the number of funds needed and for what. More specific would have been appreciated to have a more detailed understanding. I saw that someone in the comments mentioned that they have a similar project called School of Life, they could help you make an estimate maybe.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap provides milestones and horizons which give it a good initial level of audibility. However, the reason I only gave the 4-stars is that there are no metrics or KPIs provided in regards to the number of users. Nonetheless, all the other elements such as a clear problem and solution statement, and the video provided on the website.

f6_assessments.q0:
The foundation of the innovation is the trial-and-error process behind that.  The failure is a result as possible as the success.  I think that the proposers choose Cardano over other blockchains not only for the reasons exposed for them in the proposal, also because Carnado is not only a criptocurrency or a blockchain: It's an ecosystem, and like any other ecosystem in the Nature, it can give a sustainable form of life at the organisms that are borne inside of it.  The organisms take advantage of the system and the system take advantage of the organisms.  It's a mutual relation. It's a mutual favor.

So, I think this guys have the motivation and it's part of the innovation process to invest in motivated guys (and girls).  But, 12 months for having the marketplace is too much time (It's an eternity).  It's absolutely neccesary for the ecosystem to know if the new organism survives or not quickly.   6 months is a max in mi mind, better if it is 5.  

Hence, here the magic of the prototypes entry in scene.  A basic architecture, 1 or 2 tutors (the founders are excelent candidates), a short number of students (some free of charge, some at a symbolic charge of 1 ADA, some at full charge).  Students in Africa will be pleased of being part of the prototype (You could talk with WADA - https://wadalliance.org/ at respect). Non-technical tutoring for the school students in Africa will be fine.
f6_assessments.q1:
-  The proposers seem to know the problematic and the reasoning seems to be in place.  The time that will take obtain the first final results is not optimal for the reasons exposed in the previous item.

-  The proposers has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation.
f6_assessments.q2:
The measurement criteria of the proposers can provide good information to the community about the progress of the proposal, but, the time is a key factor in the effectivity of the meditions. There is no better KPI in the world that a sample of the proposal in the form of a first prototype, after a second prototype, then a third prototype, then a fourth prototype an on in on in on.
In this way, the final result is less a miracle and more an a progressive approach.

solution: Use smart contracts to store customer reviews that are verifiably associated with monetary exchange. Experts build reputations they control.
experience: Founders are a software engineer (crypto startup experience) and a physics professor—skills and connections to capture the tutoring market.
